question: Which process, in which wind or moving water carries sediment, is removing sand from Florida’s beaches?

content.source_1: Along much of Florida’s coast, waves, currents, and storms physically erode beaches by carrying sand offshore or alongshore, reducing the amount of sand on the visible beach.
content.source_2: Florida routinely conducts beach nourishment, importing and spreading sand to replace volumes lost to coastal erosion and storm-driven transport.
content.source_3: In several Florida localities, 20th-century coastal development leveled dunes and removed beach sand to create building pads and roads, directly decreasing the sand stored in the beach–dune system.
content.source_4: Dredging of tidal inlets and navigation channels in Florida extracts sand from the littoral system; when that sand is not fully bypassed to downdrift shores, adjacent beaches lose sediment because of the dredging itself.
content.source_5: Florida beach sand is predominantly quartz, which resists chemical dissolution; losses in beach sand volume arise from physical transport or removal rather than chemical breakdown.
